Tip

title: Title of the lecture; Subtitle (optional)
text:
Learning objectives
By the end of this block, you can:

Write a minimal lavaan model string
Fit it with cfa() / sem()
Interpret key parameters (loadings / paths)

title: Title of the lecture; Subtitle (optional)
text:
Minimal example (code + output)

library(lavaan)

# Toy measurement model
model <- '
  f =~ x1 + x2 + x3
'

fit <- cfa(model, data = HolzingerSwineford1939)
summary(fit, fit.measures = TRUE, standardized = TRUE)

lavaan 0.6-19 ended normally after 23 iterations

  Estimator                                         ML
  Optimization method                           NLMINB
  Number of model parameters                         6

  Number of observations                           301

Model Test User Model:
                                                      
  Test statistic                                 0.000
  Degrees of freedom                                 0

Model Test Baseline Model:

  Test statistic                               111.271
  Degrees of freedom                                 3
  P-value                                        0.000

User Model versus Baseline Model:

  Comparative Fit Index (CFI)                    1.000
  Tucker-Lewis Index (TLI)                       1.000

Loglikelihood and Information Criteria:

  Loglikelihood user model (H0)              -1356.977
  Loglikelihood unrestricted model (H1)      -1356.977
                                                      
  Akaike (AIC)                                2725.955
  Bayesian (BIC)                              2748.197
  Sample-size adjusted Bayesian (SABIC)       2729.169

Root Mean Square Error of Approximation:

  RMSEA                                          0.000
  90 Percent confidence interval - lower         0.000
  90 Percent confidence interval - upper         0.000
  P-value H_0: RMSEA <= 0.050                       NA
  P-value H_0: RMSEA >= 0.080                       NA

Standardized Root Mean Square Residual:

  SRMR                                           0.000

Parameter Estimates:

  Standard errors                             Standard
  Information                                 Expected
  Information saturated (h1) model          Structured

Latent Variables:
                   Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)   Std.lv  Std.all
  f =~                                                                  
    x1                1.000                               0.724    0.621
    x2                0.778    0.141    5.532    0.000    0.563    0.479
    x3                1.107    0.214    5.173    0.000    0.801    0.710

Variances:
                   Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)   Std.lv  Std.all
   .x1                0.835    0.118    7.064    0.000    0.835    0.614
   .x2                1.065    0.105   10.177    0.000    1.065    0.771

    f                 0.524    0.130    4.021    0.000    1.000    1.000

title: Title of the lecture; Subtitle (optional)
text:
Two-column slide (uses .two-col from slides.scss)

Concept - What is identified? - Why constraints matter? - What is the scale of a latent factor?
Quick check

inspect(fit, "converged")

[1] TRUE

fitMeasures(fit, c("cfi", "rmsea", "srmr"))

  cfi rmsea  srmr 
    1     0     0

title: Title of the lecture; Subtitle (optional)
text:
Exercise






Important


Try it (5–10 min)
1. Add x4 to the factor (if available) or remove an indicator.
2. Refit and compare fit measures.
3. What changes in the standardized loadings?

title: Title of the lecture; Subtitle (optional)
text:
Common mistakes

Treating arrows as “causal proof” (Rohrer et al., 2022)
Chasing modification indices without justification
Ignoring estimator/data-type mismatch

title: Title of the lecture; Subtitle (optional)
text:
References (manual)

Rosseel, Y. (2012). lavaan: An R package for structural equation modeling.

title: Title of the lecture; Subtitle (optional)
text:
References


Rohrer, J. M., Hünermund, P., Arslan, R. C., & Elson, M. (2022). That’s a Lot to Process! Pitfalls of Popular Path Models. Advances in Methods and Practices in Psychological Science, 5(2), 25152459221095827. https://doi.org/10.1177/25152459221095827

title: Lab X — Title
text:
By the end of this lab, you can:

Fit a model in lavaan
Inspect fit measures and key parameters
Make (and justify) one defensible diagnostic decision

title: Setup
text: This page helps you get R, packages, and the course repository running smoothly.

title: Setup
text:
1) Install/update software

R (recommended: recent CRAN release)
RStudio (recommended)
Quarto (needed only if you want to render slides/labs locally)

title: Setup
text:
2) Get the course materials

Option A — Git (recommended)

Clone the repository
Pull updates during the course if needed



Option B — Download ZIP

Download the ZIP from GitHub
Unzip and open the project folder in RStudio

title: Setup
text:
3) Install packages
Run this once (edit if you already have everything):

pkgs <- c(
  "lavaan",
  "semTools",
  "psych",
  "MVN",
  "mice",
  "modsem",
  "ggplot2",
  "dplyr",
  "tidyr"
)

to_install <- setdiff(pkgs, rownames(installed.packages()))
if (length(to_install) > 0) install.packages(to_install)

invisible(lapply(pkgs, library, character.only = TRUE))

This is lavaan 0.6-19
lavaan is FREE software! Please report any bugs.

This is semTools 0.5-7


All users of R (or SEM) are invited to submit functions or ideas for functions.

title: Setup
text:
4) Reproducibility option (recommended): renv
If the repo uses renv, you can restore the exact package versions:

# install.packages("renv")
# renv::restore()

title: Setup
section: 5) Quick test: can you run lavaan?
text:
5) Quick test: can you run lavaan?

library(lavaan)

m <- 'f =~ x1 + x2 + x3'
fit <- cfa(m, data = HolzingerSwineford1939)

inspect(fit, "converged")

[1] TRUE

fitMeasures(fit, c("cfi","rmsea","srmr"))

  cfi rmsea  srmr 
    1     0     0

title: Setup
text:
Troubleshooting

“Package X is not available”

Update R
Try a different CRAN mirror
Install from source if needed (rare)



“Quarto not found”

Install Quarto and restart RStudio



“Rendering fails”

Re-run package installation
Try rendering a single file first (e.g., one lab)
Check for path issues (especially on Windows)







Tip



If you run into errors during class, copy-paste the error message + the code you ran into your notes (or send it). It speeds up debugging a lot.

title: Labs
text:
Optional extra practice
If you want more practice beyond the core labs, check the Extras page.

title: Glossary
text: Short definitions + “what students usually confuse it with”.

title: Glossary
text:
A
Absolute fit
Fit measures that evaluate how well the model reproduces the observed covariance structure (e.g., χ², SRMR).
AIC / BIC
Information criteria for comparing models (typically non-nested too). Lower is better (with caveats).

title: Glossary
text:
C
CFA (Confirmatory Factor Analysis)
A measurement model where latent variables explain covariances among observed indicators via factor loadings.
CFI / TLI
Incremental fit indices comparing your model to a baseline (independence) model.
Cluster-robust standard errors
A correction to SEs/p-values when observations are clustered (e.g., students in classrooms) without explicitly fitting a multilevel model.
Configural / Metric / Scalar invariance
Levels of measurement invariance across groups/time: - configural: same pattern of loadings - metric: equal loadings - scalar: equal loadings + intercepts (or thresholds for ordinal)

title: Glossary
text:
D
DWLS / WLSMV
Common estimators for ordinal indicators. Naming can be confusing: the practical takeaway is that ordinal models often use a weighted least squares approach with robust corrections.

title: Glossary
text:
E
Equivalent models
Different path diagrams that imply the same covariance structure (same global fit). Fit alone cannot identify the “true” causal story.
EPC (Expected Parameter Change)
How much a parameter estimate would change if a fixed constraint were freed; often reported with modification indices.

title: Glossary
text:
F
FIML (Full Information Maximum Likelihood)
A likelihood-based approach to handle missing data under MAR assumptions (with ML-family estimators).
Fit indices (global)
Summaries of how well the overall model fits (CFI/TLI/RMSEA/SRMR/χ²).
Fit indices (local)
Diagnostics for specific parts of a model (residuals, MI/EPC, standardized residual covariances).

title: Glossary
text:
I
Identification
Whether model parameters can be uniquely estimated from the data (rules of thumb help, but do not guarantee identification).
Intercepts vs thresholds (ordinal)
- Intercepts: continuous indicator mean structure - Thresholds: cut-points that map a continuous latent response to ordinal categories

title: Glossary
text:
L
Latent variable
Unobserved construct inferred from observed indicators.
Latent interaction
An interaction between latent variables (e.g., F1 × F2 predicting Y). Estimation/interpretation differs from standard linear SEM.

title: Glossary
text:
M
Measurement model
The part of SEM that links indicators to latent factors (loadings, intercepts/thresholds, residual variances).
MI (Modification Index)
A statistic indicating how much χ² would drop if a fixed parameter were freed. Useful but easy to abuse.
Missingness (MCAR/MAR/MNAR)
Assumptions about why data are missing: - MCAR: unrelated to observed/unobserved variables - MAR: related to observed variables - MNAR: related to unobserved values themselves

title: Glossary
text:
R
RMSEA
A parsimony-adjusted fit index; usually reported with a confidence interval.

title: Glossary
text:
S
SAM (Structural After Measurement)
A two-stage estimation strategy: estimate measurement first, then structural relations using implied latent moments.
SEM (Structural Equation Model)
An integrated model including both measurement (latent variables) and structural relations (regressions/covariances among latents/observeds).
SRMR
A fit index based on standardized residuals (difference between observed and model-implied covariances/correlations).

title: Glossary
text:
T
Two-step mindset
A practical workflow: evaluate measurement quality before interpreting structural relations.







Tip



If you want to add to this glossary during the course, just make a PR / issue or send the term + how you’d define it.

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
Welcome! This book is a practical introduction to Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) for psychological research, with examples in R (mainly using lavaan).
This book is built from the course materials in the companion repository and is designed to be:

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
How to read this book

If you are new to SEM: read chapters 1–5 in order.
If you already know basics: jump to the chapter you need (ordinal, invariance, longitudinal, multilevel).
Each chapter ends with:

a summary of key points
common pitfalls
exercises (optional)

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
What you should know already

Comfortable with R (data wrangling, plotting, writing functions)
Linear regression basics
Correlation/covariance intuition

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
Companion materials

Slides and labs: see the course GitHub Pages site
Glossary: key terms and common confusions
Reporting checklist: copy-paste guidance for papers and theses
Extras: optional modules (power, latent interactions, SAM today’s methods, etc.)

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
Book roadmap

Foundations: SEM logic, identification intuition, estimation choices, lavaan grammar
Path analysis: regression models in SEM form, mediation, equivalent models
Fit & diagnostics: global vs local fit, residuals, MI discipline
CFA: measurement models, identification strategies, reliability
SEM: measurement + structure, two-step mindset, applied workflow
Extensions: missing data, invariance, ordinal SEM, longitudinal, multilevel
Appendices: lavaan recipes + reporting templates

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
Citation
If you cite this book/course notes, you can use the following format (update the year/date when final):

Feraco, T. (Year). Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences: Applied SEM with lavaan. Course notes, University of Padova.

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
Acknowledgements (optional)
Thanks to colleagues and students who provided feedback on earlier versions of these materials.

title: Extras
text: These are optional, self-contained modules you can read when relevant. Each module should include: - a short concept note (why/when) - minimal reproducible example (R code) - exercises (+ solutions if provided)

title: Extras
text:
Methods & inference

ex01 Power: Monte Carlo for SEM
ex02 Bayesian SEM: quickstart

title: Extras
text:
Advanced SEM

ex03 Latent interactions (modsem)
ex04 SAM in lavaan
ex05 MIIVs & consistent factor score regression

title: Extras
text:
Longitudinal deep dives

ex06 RI-CLPM vs CLPM
ex07 Latent change score models

title: Extras
text:
Measurement extensions

ex09 Alignment / approximate invariance
ex10 Bifactor / ESEM / method factors

title: Extras
text:
Missing data sensitivity

ex08 MNAR sensitivity: conceptual + simple strategies

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text: Welcome! This repository contains slides (Quarto revealjs), hands-on labs, and extras for self-study.

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
How to use this repo

During class: open the slides for today + run the matching lab.
After class: use the Glossary and Reporting checklist while doing exercises/projects.
Extras: optional modules (power, SAM, latent interactions, etc.) you can read when relevant.







Tip



Tip
If you get lost: come back here. This page is the “map” for everything.

text:

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
section: What you should keep open while working
text:
What you should keep open while working

Setup (only once, then keep for troubleshooting)
Glossary (quick definitions, naming conventions)
Reporting checklist (what to report in CFA/SEM/invariance/ordinal/etc.)
Extras (optional modules; useful later)

title: Structural Equation Modelling in Psychological Sciences
text:
Conventions used in this course

Core fit indices (default): χ², CFI/TLI, RMSEA (+ CI), SRMR
Local fit: residuals + MI/EPC (with “modification discipline”)
Default mindset: measurement first, then structure (“two-step mindset”)







Important



Important
Slides are optimized for live teaching. “Extras” are designed to be self-contained reading modules with code + exercises.

title: Reporting checklist
text: Use this as a copy/paste checklist for assignments, papers, and thesis chapters.

title: Reporting checklist
text:
Always report (any SEM/CFA)

Software + version (R, lavaan, semTools, etc.)
Sample size (N) and any exclusions
Variables (which indicators for each factor; scales; whether ordinal)
Estimator (ML / MLR / WLSMV etc.) + justification
Missing data handling (FIML / MI / listwise) + justification
Model syntax (append or supplement)
Model identification choices (marker vs std.lv=TRUE, constraints, etc.)
Global fit: χ²(df), CFI/TLI, RMSEA (+ CI), SRMR
Key parameters: estimates + SE/CI + standardized solution (when meaningful)
Interpretation tied to the research question
Diagnostics: what you checked (residuals, MI/EPC) and what you changed (if anything)
Reproducibility: session info (and seed if simulation)

title: Reporting checklist
text:
CFA-specific

Factor loadings (unstd + std), indicator residual variances
Factor variances/covariances
Reliability: ω (omega) and/or other chosen indices (with method stated)
Handling of cross-loadings / correlated residuals:

were any added?
what was the substantive rationale?
was this preregistered / cross-validated / replicated?

title: Reporting checklist
text:
SEM (structural) specific

Structural paths (standardized + CI)
R² for endogenous variables
Indirect effects:

method (bootstrap recommended when appropriate)
effect + CI + interpretation (avoid “p-value only” reporting)

Clarify causal language:

observational vs experimental
identification assumptions (temporal ordering, confounding, etc.)

title: Reporting checklist
text:
Multi-group / invariance

Groups (definition, Ns per group)
Invariance steps tested:

configural, metric, scalar (and strict if used)

What constraints were imposed at each step
Decision rules used (e.g., ΔCFI / ΔRMSEA thresholds) and references for your rule
If partial invariance:

which parameters freed
rationale (substantive + statistical)
what comparisons remain interpretable (e.g., latent means only after (partial) scalar)

title: Reporting checklist
text:
Ordinal indicators

Which variables treated as ordered
Estimator and link (e.g., WLSMV / probit-type default framework)
Thresholds vs intercepts (make clear what was constrained in invariance)
Fit interpretation caveat: note if thresholds or residual structures drive misfit
Sensitivity check (optional but strong): treat as continuous vs ordered and compare conclusions

title: Reporting checklist
text:
Longitudinal SEM

Time points and spacing
Whether you tested longitudinal measurement invariance
How you handled correlated uniqueness (same items across time)
For growth models:

coding of slope loadings (0,1,2… or actual time)
random effects included (intercept/slope variance)

For cross-lagged models:

clarify whether you used CLPM vs alternatives (if relevant)
interpret cross-lagged paths cautiously

title: Reporting checklist
text:
Clustered / multilevel

Clustering variable (e.g., class, clinic, therapist) and cluster sizes
Strategy used:

cluster-robust SE (and why sufficient), or
explicit multilevel model (within/between)

If multilevel:

which parameters vary within vs between
ICC motivation (optional but helpful)

title: Reporting checklist
text:
A short “results paragraph” template

“We fit a [CFA/SEM] using lavaan (version …) with estimator … . Missing data were handled using … . Model fit was [acceptable/problematic] (χ²(df)=…, CFI=…, RMSEA=… [CI], SRMR=…). The key effect of interest was … (β=…, 95% CI […, …]). Diagnostics indicated … ; we [did/did not] respecify the model. Results suggest …, with limitations including … .”








Important



Rule of thumb
If you changed the model after looking at the data, state exactly what you changed and why. “Transparency beats perfection.”

title: SEM Report — Title
text: Write 3–6 lines: - What is the substantive question? - What are the constructs? - What would be convincing evidence?

title: SEM Report — Title
text:
2.1 Sample

N =
Inclusion/exclusion =
Grouping variable (if any) =
Clustering (if any) = (e.g., students in classrooms)

title: SEM Report — Title
text:
2.2 Variables
Brief table (optional): - Indicators for each latent factor - Outcomes/predictors - Scale type (continuous vs ordinal Likert)

title: SEM Report — Title
text:
2.3 Missingness

% missing overall =
Key variables with missingness =
Strategy (FIML / MI / listwise) + short justification



Show code
# Optional quick checks (edit to match your data)
# summary(dat)
# colMeans(is.na(dat))

title: SEM Report — Title
text:
3.1 Conceptual model (diagram)
Insert a figure if you have one:

title: SEM Report — Title
text:
3.2 lavaan syntax


Show code
library(lavaan)

model <- '
  # Measurement
  f1 =~ x1 + x2 + x3
  f2 =~ y1 + y2 + y3

  # Structural
  f2 ~ f1
'

title: SEM Report — Title
text:
5.1 Global fit
Report a small set consistently (and add CI where relevant): - χ²(df) = - CFI = - TLI = - RMSEA [90% CI] = - SRMR =


Show code
# Example
# fitMeasures(fit, c("chisq","df","cfi","tli","rmsea","rmsea.ci.lower","rmsea.ci.upper","srmr"))

title: SEM Report — Title
text:
5.2 Key parameters
Focus on the parameters tied to your research question. - Main paths (standardized estimates + CI) - Loadings (and any problematic indicators) - R² for outcomes


Show code
# Example: parameter table
# pe <- parameterEstimates(fit, standardized = TRUE)
# pe[pe$op %in% c("~","=~"), c("lhs","op","rhs","est","se","pvalue","std.all")]

title: SEM Report — Title
text:
5.3 Interpretation (write-up)
Write 1–2 short paragraphs: - What do the results mean substantively? - Are effects small/medium/large in context? - What alternative explanations remain?
Include citations when relevant, e.g. (rosseel2012lavaan?).

title: SEM Report — Title
text: 10.1 References
